awd_titl_txt: Photoinitiated Dynamics of Transient Species: Hydrogen-Bonded Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms - A (CSDM-A) and Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Programs of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Hanna Reisler of the University of Southern California uses lasers to initiate chemical reactions and then observe how the molecules dissociate (fall apart), dissipate the energy they absorbed from the laser light, or behave as acids under light exposure. The Reisler group is particularly interested in hydrogen-bonded complexes of molecules and nanoparticles in water containing a few molecules of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and organic molecules such as benzene or phenol.  Hydrogen bonds are formed from the attraction of partially negatively-charged atoms such as oxygen on one molecule and the partially positive charge of a hydrogen atom on a neighboring molecule. Hydrogen-bonded networks influence chemical and biological function and are implicated in the identity of icy bodies in the solar system. Hydrogen bonding is not yet well understood because of difficulties in defining the experimental conditions. Professor Reisler overcomes these challenges by selecting water aggregates that contain a specific number of solute molecules, then uses laser techniques that have high detection sensitivity for the molecules and reactions of interest. The broader impacts of the project include potential societal benefits arising from better understanding the effects of hydrogen bonding on the reactivity of molecules in the atmosphere and other water-rich environments, like the human body.  Students and postdoctoral researchers build advanced instrumentation, preparing them high technology careers. Professor Reisler, a leader in mentoring of women in science fields, continues her activities in encouraging students from underrepresented groups to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

The current research focuses on three topics: (1) energy flow pathways in the predissociation of dimers of water with aromatic molecules;(2) measurements of hydrogen-bond dissociation energies in cyclic trimers and tetramers with specific HCl and water subunits; and (3) interactions of nanoscale water samples with protons.  By recording images of specific rovibrational levels of one fragment of the dissociated cluster, the rovibrational energy distributions in the cofragments are determined, demonstrating how geometry and hydrogen-bonding type influence energy disposal. This provides stringent tests of theories and proposed mechanisms.  In order to study the emergence of acidity in condensed phase aggregates, nanofabricated arrays of gold nanoparticles are covered with solid water and rapid heating is achieved by visible irradiation that excites the plasmon resonance of the gold nanoparticles. A 0.5 mm diameter laser pulse excites over a million nanoparticles.  The effect of a single laser pulse on solid water doped with HCl is studied using isotope exchange to probe acidity.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

The NSF-funded project focused on state-specific studies of vibrational predissociation (VP) dynamics of hydrogen-bonded (H-bonded) clusters of water with HCl and aromatic molecules, and on nanoscale studies that explored chemical reactions leading to acidity in the condensed phase. In studies of the VP of small clusters, vibrational state specificity was explored. Work on clusters of HCl with several water molecules and the phenol-water dimer was completed. A novel approach for the preparation of well-defined nanoscale samples of solid water was developed, which exploited rapid heating using 532-nm irradiation of gold nanoparticles aided by plasmon resonance. A proof-of-principle demonstration was the excitation of NO2 / N2O4 samples embedded in layers of frozen water, which promoted the creation of nitric acid. Integral to the experimental studies were comparisons with theoretical calculations and simulations carried out with collaborators.

Intellectual Merit:

Energy flow, bond rupture, and energy disposal in VP of H-bonded systems (clusters and condensed phases) are topics that are still not well understood. Molecular-level mechanistic insights were obtained through a combination of detailed experimental studies and high-level electronic structure and dynamical calculations. The experimental results serve to test the quality of potential energy surfaces far from equilibrium and elucidate vibrational energy flow patterns that impact condensed phase behavior.  Three projects were completed.

In cyclic trimers and tetramers of HCl with water, energy flow pathways that led to elimination of HCl and water monomers were elucidated, showing that cyclic clusters of HCl with three water molecules do not lead to ionization of HCl.  Both HCl and water monomers were identified as products following vibrational excitation of the OH stretch vibration of water. Complementary theoretical calculations gave insights into the dissociation mechanism. Satisfactory agreement between theory and experiment was achieved when comparing the monomer fragments? rotational energies, the shapes of the fragments? speed distributions, and the average fragment speeds and translational energies. Insights into the dissociation mechanism and lifetime were gained from quasiclassical trajectory calculations, which were performed on a previously reported many-body potential energy surface. Exciting two different H-bonded OH stretch vibrations of the cluster did not affect the dissociation rates and product energy distributions. It is concluded that the dissociation lifetime is on the order of 10 ps and that the final trimer products are in their lowest energy cyclic forms. These results indicate that the dissociation mechanism follows trends congruent with smaller neutral clusters. These trends were described in a review article published in Chemical Reviews.

 

In the VP of dimers of aromatic molecules with water, the goal was to establish propensity rules for vibrational and translational energy disposal, and their dependence on the excited vibrational mode. The VP of the phenol-water dimer was investigated by detecting water fragments following IR laser excitation of either the H-bonded OH stretch of the phenol subunit or the free OH stretch of water. The rotational energy distribution of the water fragment was characterized. Images taken by monitoring selected rotational levels of the water fragment provided internal energy distributions of the phenol product pair-correlated with specific rotational levels of the water fragment.  Comparing the observed energy distributions with predictions of statistical theories revealed that when exciting the H-bonded OH stretch, a statistical behavior was observed, and vibrational energy redistribution within the phenol unit preceded coupling to the intermolecular modes of the dimer. In contrast, when the OH stretch vibration of water was excited, deviations from the predictions of statistical theories were observed, indicating that energy redistribution in the dimer was incomplete before dissociation.  Similar studies with pyrazine-water were complicated by intra-cluster side reactions.

A novel experimental strategy for studying fragile nanoscale samples was devised and implemented in which a combination of nanoimprint lithography and pulsed laser photoinitiation was used to initiate chemical reactions. An array of gold nanoparticles absorbs pulsed laser radiation and the heat is transferred to molecules embedded in ice thin films atop the nanoparticles. Each nanoparticle acts independently, providing the results of millions of "nano-experiments," initiated by a single laser pulse. An application to a chemical system was demonstrated in which isotope scrambling is used to infer the presence of nitric acid products from NO2/N2O4.  Extension to other chemical applications is straightforward.

Broader Impacts:

Hydrogen bonds are major players in environments ranging from living cells to icy bodies in the solar system. They are important in biological systems, molecular solids, and hydrated solutions. Graduate students on the project learn problem-solving techniques applied to broad areas of science and technology that prepare them for jobs in the high technology workforce and in academia. The research is integrated into General Chemistry courses and graduate classes on photoinitiated dynamics. The PI has taken leadership roles in mentoring women in STEM fields at all stages of their careers.
